results.title: Facebook’s Apps Went Down. The World Saw How Much It Runs on Them.
results.abstract: The outage disrupted the digital lives of small-business owners, politicians, aid workers and others. But for some, it was a welcome reprieve.

results.title: French Report Casts New Light on Sexual Abuse in Catholic Church
results.abstract: An independent commission laid out in detail the extent of the problem and the church’s failure to tackle it, estimating that about 216,000 minors had been abused since 1950.

multimedia.caption: Easter celebrations at a church in Paris this year. The report was the most extensive account to date of the scope of sexual abuse by clergy in France, especially against children and vulnerable people.

results.title: The End of a ‘Gilded Age’: China Is Bringing Business to Heel
results.abstract: Executives sit in jail, tech companies are being reined in and the biggest developer is teetering. It’s the beginning of a new era for China’s economy.

results.title: Thailand’s Quarantine-Island Experiment Is Showing (Modest) Results
results.abstract: Phuket, a resort island where vaccinated people who test negative for the coronavirus can roam freely, is starting to see some life return to its tourism industry.

results.title: A Dispatch From an Endangered Bird’s ‘Garden of Eden’
results.abstract: Immerse yourself in the visual splendor of a tiny volcanic island in the northern Andaman Sea, the only home of the little-known Narcondam hornbill.

multimedia.caption: The Narcondam hornbill (Rhyticeros narcondami) is endemic to the tiny island of Narcondam, which is about 160 miles northeast of Port Blair in the Andaman Islands.

results.title: U.S. Signals No Thaw in Trade Relations With China
results.abstract: The Biden administration said it would not immediately remove the Trump administration’s tariffs and would require that Beijing uphold its trade commitments.
results.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

multimedia.caption: The Shanghai port in June. “We continue to have serious concerns” about China’s trade practices, said Katherine Tai, the United States trade representative.
The Shanghai port in June. “We continue to have serious concerns” about China’s trade practices, said Katherine Tai, the United States trade representative.

results.title: Hungary’s Leader Fights Criticism in U.S. via Vast Influence Campaign
results.abstract: Viktor Orban, the country’s far-right prime minister, has spent millions on lobbying, support for think tanks and cultivating allies in Washington.
results.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Benjamin Novak

multimedia.caption: Former Vice President Mike Pence’s visit to Hungary last month was one of several by U.S. conservatives wooed by allies of Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
